III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Visitation and family time; in person contact
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421
Section • (1) An agency shall develop a plan of visitation and family
Description time for each child in foster care consistent with the child's
service plans, as required by R 400.12419 and R
400.12420 to ensure the safety and well-being of the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are concerns that the agency is not following parenting time
protocols regarding a specific foster care case.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Parent A - On 4/18/2024 Parent A was interviewed by phone. Her
fiancé, Parent B, could also be heard talking and answering
questions in the background. Parent A stated she believes Foster
Care Worker is not allowing required visitation. Parent A reported
she and her Parent B were visiting their 5 oldest children twice per
week until Foster Care Worker had the Judge order the visits to be
reduced to once per week. Parent A stated she and Parent B are
still able to visit their infant son 3 times per week. Parent A stated
the court ordered the parents arrive one hour prior to every visit
and if she is a few minutes late, Foster Care Worker will cancel
the visit. Parent A feels she should get a 15-minute grace period
like other families working with the agency. She reported that
there was one visit during which Parent B left to get pizza for the
kids after which an agency supervisor would not allow him back
into the visit. Parent A stated her children were upset, so she told
them it will all be over soon. An agency supervisor then made
Parent A leave the visit due to talking with the children about the
case, despite Parent A stating she was referring to the current visit
situation, not the case. Parent A stated she has never missed a
visit unless it was cancelled due being a few minutes late. She
added that Foster Care Worker scheduled a well-child visit for her
infant right before parenting time with the other children, so to
make her parenting time, she had to leave the well child visit and
miss the administration of her infant’s vaccines.
Foster Care Worker - On 4/18/2024 Foster Care Worker was
interviewed via video conferencing. She reported the court
ordered parenting times be reduced from twice per week to once
per week with a requirement that the parents arrive 1 hour prior to
the visit. Foster Care Worker stated the early arrival time was
2

previously ordered to be 30 minutes, but the parents were
continually arriving late causing the children to spend unnecessary
time in the car, so the time was increased. Since the increase, the
parents have improved their compliance. She stated there have
been times in the past when the parents called and stated they
would be 10 minutes late and the visit would still be allowed, but
the parents seemingly took advantage of that leniency by
repeatedly coming late, so Foster Care Worker has to be stricter.
Foster Care Worker stated she recalled the incident when Parent
B left to get pizza. Foster Care Worker reported she, the agency
case aide, and an agency supervisor all told him he would not be
allowed back in if he left. She stated he signed an agency
parenting time rules document at least once, which outlines that
parents cannot leave and come back to visits. Parent B left
anyway and was not allowed back into the visit. Parent A became
upset and verbally aggressive with the workers and supervisor, so
the supervisor ended the visit.
Foster Care Worker stated the foster parents both work and the
infant child’s medical appointments are typically scheduled after
they get home from work which is typically 4-4:30pm. On the date
of the infant’s well child Parent A is referring to; the parents were
allowed to arrive at the start of the 5:00pm parenting time with the
other children rather than an hour early so they could attend the
medical appointment. The appointment ended up running long, so
the parents had to leave the appointment before the vaccines
were administered, as the other children were already at the office
waiting for their parents. Foster Care Worker stated she has since
been more mindful of when medical appointments are scheduled
so they don’t conflict with parenting time.
Foster Care Supervisor – On 4/19/2024 Foster Care Supervisor
was interviewed via video conferencing. She reported being aware
that Parent A and Parent B are unhappy about the court orders
regarding their visitation. They have requested meetings to talk
about parenting time with the worker and supervision twice;
however, they did not show up to either meeting. Foster Care
Supervisor stated the parents were previously ordered to arrive 30
minutes prior to their scheduled visit, but they frequently arrived
late or not all, so the early arrival time was increased to one hour.
Additionally, based on the frequency of their missed visitation, the
court reduced parenting time with the older children to one hour
per week. When told the parents reported having never missed a
visit during their interview, Foster Care Supervisor replied that is
not true, indicating the most recently missed visit was before this
interview. She added they did attend parenting time with their
3

infant child twice earlier in the week, but they left both visits an
hour early.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
The following documents were reviewed in the electronic case
record:
• 5/23/2023 Court Order– Parents shall arrive 30 minutes
early to every visit
• 10/24/2023 Court Order – Family is to arrive 1 hour prior to
scheduled parenting time
• 1/23/2024 Court Order - Parenting time reduced to 1 hour,
mother to have no unsupervised contact with youths, all
other orders remain
• Parenting Time Ground Rules document signed by Parent
A & Parent B on 4/17/2022 & 4/22/2023
• Case Service Plan covering 12/1/2023-2/21/2024
• 2/21/2024 Visitation Plan indicating supervised parenting
time is to occur once per week for one hour
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as staff are following the court
ordered parenting time requirements.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
April 30, 2024

Holly Austin Date
